title: South Florida New Developments Launching Sales Offer Units With Next-Level Amenities
text:
After a slow first six months of the year, the luxury market in Miami-Dade County, Florida, rebounded significantly in July, up 15% compared to July 2018, according to the South Florida Regional Multiple Listing Service.

“July was a big month for us, after January through June being not so great,” said Ron Shuffield, president & CEO of Miami-based Berkshire Hathaway HomeServices EWM Realty. “We were down 13% in the number of units sold over $1 million from the previous year.”

July “was the first month that we sold more than last year (comparing month over month),” he said. There were 188 luxury units sold in Miami-Dade County in July, compared to 164 in July 2018, according to the MLS.

In the overall Miami-Dade market, single-family home sales rose 15% year-over-year in July, from 1,104 to 1,270, according to the Miami Association of Realtors.

“Sellers have finally come to the party,” Mr. Shuffield said. “We’ve been watching sales soften since the latter part of 2015,” and then prices began to weaken in 2016 and “we’ve continued to see that.”

“We have more luxury buyers than ever, but they’re not in a hurry,” he said. “They’re willing to wait on the sidelines until they see what they want—now they are beginning to strike and close on deals.”

“Most of the activity has been from U.S. buyers from high-tax states like New York, New Jersey and California,” said Danny Hertzberg of The Jills Zeder Group, affiliated with Coldwell Banker Residential Real Estate.

There has been a complete shift from the “international buyer to the domestic buyer,” Mr. Hertzberg said.

The driving factor for domestic buyers is tax savings, but “secondly, Miami is growing and becoming a truly international city, with more cultural offerings,” he said.

Luxury market inventory in Miami has been “decreasing somewhat, which is a good thing,” Mr. Shuffield said.

“Sixty-one percent of our inventory is condos right now, with single-family homes at 39%,” he added.

Interestingly, the number of sales is the reverse of that—61% of sales are single-family, with condos at 39%, Mr. Shuffield said.

He attributes this to the dip in the South Florida international market. “Most international buyers through the years have purchased condos,” he said.

The high end of the market, especially for single-family homes on the waterfront, “has never been stronger,” Mr. Hertzberg said.

The market for homes on the gate-guarded islands in Biscayne Bay, such as Star, Palm, and Hibiscus islands, is “particularly strong,” he said.

Summers are typically slow, “yet we’ve had multiple deals in the $10 million to $20 million range for single-family homes,” Mr. Hertzberg said.

That augments well for a busy winter season, which typically runs from November to April or May, he said.
